name: Mercury
description:
• Smallest planet in our solar system
• Closest planet to the Sun
• Fastest planet, zipping around the Sun every 88 Earth days
• Has the most extreme temperature variations
• Not the hottest planet despite being closest to Sun (Venus is hotter)

name: Venus
description:
• Hottest planet in solar system (462°C) due to greenhouse effect
• Rotates backwards (retrograde rotation)
• Longest day of any planet (243 Earth days)
• Brightest planet visible from Earth
• Surface pressure 92 times greater than Earth's

metadata.atmosphere: 96% CO2, 3% N2, thick clouds of sulfuric acid

name: Earth
description:
• Only known planet to support life
• 71% of surface covered by water
• Has active plate tectonics
• Magnetic field protects from solar radiation
• Only planet not named after a god/goddess

name: Mars
description:
• Known as the Red Planet due to iron oxide on surface
• Home to Olympus Mons, largest volcano in solar system
• Has the largest canyon, Valles Marineris
• Evidence of ancient water flows
• Target for future human exploration

name: Jupiter
description:
• Largest planet in solar system
• More than 1,000 Earths could fit inside
• Great Red Spot is a storm larger than Earth
• Fastest rotation of any planet
• Acts as 'vacuum cleaner' protecting inner planets

metadata.atmosphere: 89% H2, 10% He, traces of methane, ammonia

name: Saturn
description:
• Most spectacular ring system of any planet
• Least dense planet - would float in water
• Hexagonal storm at north pole
• Moon Titan has thick atmosphere and liquid methane lakes
• Most moons of any planet (146 confirmed)

name: Uranus
description:
• Rotates on its side (98° axial tilt)
• Coldest planetary atmosphere in solar system
• First planet discovered with telescope
• Methane gives it blue-green color
• Rings discovered in 1977

name: Neptune
description:
• Winds up to 2,100 km/h - fastest in solar system
• Discovered through mathematical prediction
• Deep blue color from methane absorption
• Moon Triton orbits backwards
• Only planet not visible to naked eye

name: Sun (Sol)
description:
The star at the center of our Solar System.

• Contains 99.86% of solar system's mass
• Light takes 8 minutes 20 seconds to reach Earth
• Converts 4 million tons of matter to energy every second
• Will become red giant in 5 billion years
• Travels at 828,000 km/h around galactic center

name: Sirius (Alpha Canis Majoris)
description:
• Brightest star in night sky
• Binary system with white dwarf companion
• Called 'Dog Star'
• 8.7 light years from Earth

name: Canopus (Alpha Carinae)
description:
• Second brightest star in night sky
• Best seen from Southern Hemisphere
• Used for spacecraft navigation
• Giant star 10x Sun's mass

name: Arcturus (Alpha Boötis)
description:
• Fourth brightest star in night sky
• Red giant star
• Fast moving through space
• Name means 'Guardian of the Bear'

name: Vega (Alpha Lyrae)
description:
• Fifth brightest star in night sky
• First star photographed (1850)
• First star with spectrum recorded
• Pole star in 14,000 CE

name: Rigel (Beta Orionis)
description:
• Seventh brightest star in night sky
• Blue supergiant
• Most luminous star near Earth
• Orion's left foot

name: Betelgeuse (Alpha Orionis)
description:
• Ninth brightest star in night sky
• Red supergiant
• Expected to go supernova
• Orion's right shoulder
• If at Sun's center, would reach Jupiter

name: Alpha Centauri
description:
• Closest star system to Sun
• Triple star system
• Proxima Centauri is closest at 4.24 ly
• Alpha Cen A similar to our Sun

name: Altair (Alpha Aquilae)
description:
• Twelfth brightest star
• Rotates rapidly (9 hours)
• Flattened at poles
• Summer Triangle member

name: Aldebaran (Alpha Tauri)
description:
• Fourteenth brightest star
• Red giant
• Bull's eye in Taurus
• Name means 'The Follower'

name: Antares (Alpha Scorpii)
description:
• Sixteenth brightest star
• Red supergiant
• Heart of the Scorpion
• Name means 'Rival of Mars'
• Will explode as supernova

name: Polaris (Alpha Ursae Minoris)
description:
• Current North Star
• Triple star system
• Used for navigation for centuries
• Position changes over millennia

name: Moon (Luna)
description:
• Fifth largest moon in solar system
• Same side always faces Earth (tidally locked)
• Causes Earth's tides
• Only celestial body visited by humans
• Moving away from Earth 3.8 cm per year

name: Phobos
description:
• Larger and closer of Mars' two moons
• Orbiting closer than any other moon to its planet
• Will eventually crash into Mars or break into rings
• Heavily cratered surface

name: Deimos
description:
• Smaller and more distant Mars moon
• Smoothest body in solar system due to dust
• May be captured asteroid

name: Io
description:
• Most volcanically active body in solar system
• Over 400 active volcanoes
• Surface constantly being resurfaced
• Tidal heating from Jupiter causes volcanism
• Yellow-orange color from sulfur compounds

name: Europa
description:
• Icy surface may hide subsurface ocean
• Most likely place for extraterrestrial life
• Smoothest surface of any solid body
• Ice shell 15-25 km thick
• Water plumes detected erupting from surface

name: Ganymede
description:
• Largest moon in solar system
• Larger than planet Mercury
• Only moon with its own magnetic field
• Has subsurface ocean
• Dark and light terrains on surface

name: Callisto
description:
• Second largest moon of Jupiter
• Most heavily cratered object in solar system
• Ancient surface unchanged for billions of years
• May have subsurface ocean
• Outermost Galilean moon

name: Titan
description:
• Largest moon of Saturn
• Only moon with thick atmosphere
• Lakes and rivers of liquid methane
• Huygens probe landed on surface in 2005
• Atmosphere mostly nitrogen like Earth

name: Enceladus
description:
• Brightest object in solar system (reflects 100% light)
• Geysers erupt from south pole 'tiger stripes'
• Subsurface global ocean confirmed
• All ingredients for life present
• Feeds Saturn's E-ring with ice particles

name: Triton
description:
• Largest moon of Neptune
• Orbits backwards (retrograde)
• Coldest known surface in solar system (-235°C)
• Active geysers of nitrogen gas
• Likely captured Kuiper Belt object

name: Orion Nebula (M42)
description:
• Brightest nebula in sky
• Visible to naked eye
• Stellar nursery with 700+ young stars
• Part of Orion's sword
• Four Trapezium stars at center

name: Crab Nebula (M1)
description:
• Result of supernova observed in 1054 AD
• Contains pulsar at center
• Expanding at 1,500 km/s
• Source of X-rays and gamma rays
• First object in Messier catalog

name: Eagle Nebula (M16)
description:
• Famous 'Pillars of Creation'
• Active star-forming region
• Pillars are being eroded by radiation
• Hubble's iconic image

name: Ring Nebula (M57)
description:
• Classic planetary nebula
• Shell of gas from dying star
• Central white dwarf visible
• Football-shaped, viewed from end

name: Horsehead Nebula (Barnard 33)
description:
• Dark nebula silhouetted against bright background
• Horse head shape
• Part of Orion Molecular Cloud Complex
• Star formation occurring within

name: Helix Nebula (NGC 7293)
description:
• Closest planetary nebula to Earth
• Called 'Eye of God'
• Complex structure with rings
• Central star becoming white dwarf

name: Milky Way
description:
• Our home galaxy
• Contains supermassive black hole Sagittarius A*
• Part of Local Group
• Will collide with Andromeda in 4.5 billion years
• Takes 230 million years to orbit galactic center

name: Andromeda Galaxy (M31)
description:
• Closest major galaxy to Milky Way
• Largest galaxy in Local Group
• Visible to naked eye
• Approaching Milky Way at 110 km/s
• Collision expected in 4.5 billion years

name: Triangulum Galaxy (M33)
description:
• Third largest in Local Group
• Visible to naked eye in dark skies
• Intense star formation in nucleus
• May be satellite of Andromeda

name: Whirlpool Galaxy (M51)
description:
• Classic grand design spiral
• Interacting with companion galaxy NGC 5195
• First galaxy classified as spiral
• Many young star clusters

name: Sombrero Galaxy (M104)
description:
• Named for hat-like appearance
• Bright nucleus and prominent dust lane
• Many globular clusters
• Strong X-ray source from center

name: Large Magellanic Cloud
description:
• Satellite galaxy of Milky Way
• Fourth largest galaxy in Local Group
• Rich in star formation
• Tarantula Nebula located here
• Visible from Southern Hemisphere

name: Messier 87 (Virgo A)
description:
• Home to first imaged black hole
• Giant elliptical galaxy
• Massive jet 5,000 light years long
• Trillions of stars
• Supermassive black hole 6.5 billion solar masses

name: Ceres
description:
• Largest object in asteroid belt
• First asteroid discovered
• Classified as dwarf planet in 2006
• Has bright spots (salt deposits)

name: Vesta
description:
• Second most massive asteroid
• Visited by Dawn spacecraft 2011
• Has giant crater at south pole
• Source of many meteorites

name: Pallas
description:
• Third largest asteroid
• Highly inclined orbit
• Heavily cratered surface

name: Hygiea
description:
• Fourth largest asteroid
• May be classified as dwarf planet
• Dark carbon-rich surface

name: TRAPPIST-1 System
description:
System with 7 known planets.



• All planets Earth-sized
• Three planets in habitable zone
• Planets very close together
• All likely tidally locked
• Best system for studying Earth-sized atmospheres

name: Proxima Centauri System
description:
System with 2 known planets.



• Closest star system to Sun
• Proxima b in habitable zone
• Red dwarf star - very active
• Flares could affect habitability

name: Kepler-186 System
description:
System with 5 known planets.



• First Earth-sized planet in habitable zone
• Kepler-186f is habitable zone planet
• All planets smaller than Neptune
• Red dwarf host star

name: HD 209458 System
description:
System with 1 known planets.



• First transiting exoplanet discovered
• First exoplanet with detected atmosphere
• Planet is 'hot Jupiter'
• Atmosphere contains sodium and hydrogen

name: 51 Pegasi System
description:
System with 1 known planets.



• First exoplanet around Sun-like star
• 51 Pegasi b is 'hot Jupiter'
• Discovery confirmed exoplanets exist
• Nobel Prize awarded for discovery in 2019
